titleStmt.title: Fundamental-frequency discrimination based on temporal-envelope cues: Effects of bandwidth and interference

analytic.title: Fundamental-frequency discrimination based on temporal-envelope cues: Effects of bandwidth and interference

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Both music and speech perception rely on hearing out one pitch in the presence of others.

Pitch discrimination of narrowband sounds based only on temporal-envelope cues is rendered nearly impossible by introducing interferers in both normal-hearing listeners and cochlear-implant (CI) users.
This study tested whether performance improves in normal-hearing listeners if the target is presented over a broad spectral region.

The results indicate that performance is still strongly affected by spectrally remote interferers, despite increases in bandwidth, suggesting that envelope-based pitch is unlikely to allow CI users to perceive pitch when multiple harmonic sounds are presented at once.

Limited pitch information is available to cochlear implant (CI) users (McDermott, 2004) and pitch discrimination for complex tones is considerably poorer in CI users than in normal-hearing (NH) listeners, with discrimination thresholds that are higher by an order of magnitude or more (Oxenham, 2018).

This deficit is due in part to the fact that CI users only have access to temporal cues, based on the envelope repetition rate of the stimulus, or the pulse rate itself (Busby and Clark, 1997;Kong et al., 2009), because neither the place nor the timing information from lower-numbered spectrally resolved harmonics that provide NH listeners with the most salient pitch are available via CIs (Mehta and Oxenham, 2017).

This difficulty for CI users seems to be exacerbated in the presence of interfering pitch sounds, where discrimination is rendered almost impossible, with discrimination thresholds exceeding 100% of the fundamental frequency (F0), when an interfering source is added, even when it is remote in spectral location (Kreft et al., 2013).

Interestingly, NH listeners show similarly dramatic pitch discrimination interference (PDI) (Gockel et al., 2004) when presented with stimuli that resemble those provided to CI users (Carlyon et al., 2007;Kreft et al., 2013).
In NH listeners, F0 discrimination of complex tones can improve dramatically when the bandwidth of the stimulus is increased (Houtsma and Smurzynski, 1990;Kaernbach and Bering, 2001).
It is not known whether an increase in stimulus bandwidth also leads to reduced susceptibility to pitch discrimination interference.

However, the fact that more salient (and more accurate) pitch provided by resolved harmonics is less susceptible to PDI suggests that broadening the bandwidth of stimuli with unresolved harmonics, and thus making the pitch more salient, may improve its resilience against interference.
The aim of the current study was to investigate whether susceptibility to interference decreases with an increase in bandwidth in NH listeners.

If pitch interference can be mitigated by increases in stimulus bandwidth, it may be possible to induce the perception of multiple pitches via a CI, if each pitch is represented by more than one electrode.
This idea was tested here by using a paradigm similar to that of Kreft et al. (2013), while increasing the bandwidth of the stimuli.

Fundamental-frequency difference limens (F0DLs) were measured in the presence of interfering complex tones that were spectrally overlapping or spectrally remote, relative to the target stimulus, as a function of stimulus bandwidth.
The interferers were presented either synchronously with the target or were gated on before and gated off after the target stimulus.
The results show that discrimination is not greatly improved by increasing the stimulus bandwidth, with or without the presence of interferers.
This outcome suggests that increasing the stimulus bandwidth (or number of electrodes) will not in itself improve pitch salience sufficiently to enable the perception of multiple pitches via a CI.
2. Experiment 1: Pitch discrimination interference with only temporal-envelope cues
The paradigm used by Kreft et al. (2013) used narrowband stimuli to measure pitch discrimination interference.

The stimuli were so-called transposed tones (van de Par and Kohlrausch, 1997), where the 10-dB bandwidth of the target tone complex was approximately one tenth of an octave, resulting in the inclusion of only five components.
It is possible that the narrow bandwidth and small number of components resulted in weak pitch salience, which in turn caused more susceptibility to interference.

In experiment 1, we increased the bandwidth to 1250 Hz (from 5000 to 6250 Hz) with an average of about ten components within the passband of each stimulus, which should result in a more salient pitch (Houtsma and Smurzynski, 1990).
The F0, and spectral region of the interferer were varied, along with the target-interferer synchrony, to investigate the extent and nature of interference on F0DLs.

Twelve subjects (nine female, three male), ranging in age from 18 to 24 years with audiometric thresholds no greater than 15 dB hearing level (HL) at octave frequencies from 250 to 8000 Hz were tested.
In fact, all participants had audiometric thresholds at 8 kHz of no more than 5 dB HL, suggesting good high-frequency hearing.
No participant reported a history of neurological or hearing disorders.
Written informed consent was provided by each participant, and all participants were compensated for their time.
The experiment was conducted at the University of Minnesota -Twin Cities.
The protocol was approved by the University of Minnesota Institutional Review Board.

The target stimulus for the experiment was a complex harmonic tone with a nominal F0 of 115 Hz, bandpass filtered with corner frequencies of 5000 and 6250 Hz and filter slopes of 72 dB/octave on either side of the passband.
The duration of the target was 300 ms (including 10-ms onset and offset raised-cosine ramps).
The level per component was set at a nominal 50 dB sound pressure level (SPL) but was roved on each presentation within a range of 66 dB to reduce potential loudness cues.

The interferer stimulus, in conditions when interferers were present, was also a bandpass-filtered harmonic complex, with passbands of 2800-4050 Hz (low), 5000-6250 Hz (middle), or 8000-9250 Hz (high), with the same spectral slopes of 72 dB/octave as the target.
All complex tones (target and interferers) were presented in sine phase.

The F0 of the interferer was either 115 Hz (SAME condition), 9 semitones below the target F0 (LOW condition), 9 semitones above the target F0 (HIGH condition), or an F0 chosen at random between 6 and 12 semitones below the target F0 (RAND condition) in each interval of each trial.

It is generally accepted that harmonics above the 12th are spectrally unresolved for F0s around 100 Hz (Houtsma and Smurzynski, 1990;Shackleton and Carlyon, 1994) so all the harmonics in the target as well as the interferers would be clearly unresolved.
The level of the interferer was also 50 dB SPL per component (with no roving).
The interferer was either presented synchronously or asynchronously with the target.

In the synchronous conditions, the interferer was gated on and off with the target; in the asynchronous conditions, the interferer began 200 ms before the target onset and ended 200 ms after the target offset.
The interferer was also gated on and off with 10-ms raised-cosine ramps.

All stimuli were presented in a background of threshold-equalizing noise (TEN) (Moore et al., 2000) with a level of 40 dB SPL per equivalent rectangular bandwidth (ERB) at 1 kHz (i.e., 10 dB below the nominal level per component of the stimuli).

For six of the twelve participants, the TEN was simply bandpass filtered between 20 and 12 000 Hz; for the other six participants, spectral notches were introduced in the regions corresponding to the bandpass regions of the target and interferer to improve the audibility of the target while still ensuring that any potential distortion products remained masked.
Experiments were administered in a double-walled sound attenuating booth and sounds were presented via HD650 headphones (Sennheiser, Old Lyme, CT).
These headphones have a frequency response that resembles the average diffuse-field response, as confirmed by measurements with a Bruel & Kjaer artificial ear (model 4153).

These headphones have been used in previous experiments where stimulus frequencies have been presented (and have been found to be audible) up to 16 kHz at levels of no more than 55 dB SPL per component [e.g., Lau et al. (2017)].
All stimuli were generated in MATLAB (The Mathworks, Natick, MA) via a 24-bit L22 soundcard (LynxStudio, Costa Mesa, CA) with a sampling rate of 48 kHz and were presented monaurally to the left ear.

For all the tasks, thresholds were obtained using a twointerval two-alternative forced-choice task, with an adaptive three-down one-up procedure that tracks the 79.4% point on the psychometric function (Levitt, 1971).

For each trial, each interval had target F0s geometrically centered on the nominal target frequency of 115 Hz, so that one interval had a lower F0 and the other had a higher F0 and the difference between the two, DF0, was the F0 difference, expressed as a percentage of the lower F0.
The starting value of DF was 20%.

Initially the value of DF0 increased or decreased by a factor of 2. The step size was decreased to a factor of 1.41 after the first two reversals in the adaptive procedure, and to a factor of 1.19 after the next two reversals.
An additional six reversals occurred at the smallest step size, and the F0DL was calculated as the geometric mean of the DF0 values at those last six reversal points.
Each condition was presented once before any was repeated.
The order of conditions was randomized across repetitions and across subjects.
All the conditions were repeated four times per participant.
The geometric mean across repetitions was defined as the F0DL for each participant per condition.
All analyses were carried out on the log-transformed F0DLs.

A mixed-model repeatedmeasures analysis of variance (ANOVA) was run on conditions with an interferer present, with F0DLs as the dependent variable, a between-subjects factor of the presence of the spectral notches in the TEN (notches present or absent), and within-subjects factors of interferer synchrony (synchronous/asynchronous), F0 of interferer (low, same, high, or rand) and spectral region of interferer (low, same, high).

No significant effect of the presence of the notch was observed [F(1,10) ¼ 0.78, p ¼ 0.398] and no interactions with notch were found (p > 0.5 in all cases), suggesting that the notches did not improve sensitivity.
For this reason, the data between the two groups of participants were combined and are shown in Fig. 1.
Mean data are shown as bars, and individual data are shown as dots in each condition.

A significant main effect of the spectral region of the interferer was observed [F(2,20) ¼ 100, p < 0.001], reflecting the generally poorer (higher) thresholds when the interferer was in the same spectral region as the target.

There was no main effect of synchrony [F(1,10) ¼ 0.93, p ¼ 0.357] or interferer F0 [F(3,30) ¼ 3.65, p ¼ 0.62], although there was a significant interaction between synchrony of the interferer and the spectral region of the interferer [F(2,20) ¼ 18.3, p < 0.001].
No other interactions were significant.

Post hoc tests for the spectral region indicated a significant difference between all three spectral regions of the interferer (Bonferroni corrected p < 0.001 in all cases) as well as a significant difference between the interferer conditions and the no-interferer conditions (p < 0.001 in all cases).
Average F0DLs were 31.3%, 72.4%, and 17.8% when the interferer was in the low, same, and high spectral regions, respectively.
This pattern of reduced interference for the high-frequency interferer is in good agreement with previous studies of pitch discrimination interference (Gockel et al., 2004).
The average F0DL in the absence of an interferer was 7.24%.

To further investigate the significant interaction between spectral region and synchrony of the interferer, we pooled the data across all participants (ignoring the notch/no-notch distinction) as well as across different F0 conditions.

Pairwise comparisons of the average low, same, and high spectrum regions across different synchrony conditions showed only a significant difference between the synchronous and asynchronous conditions when the spectral region was the same [t(1,11) ¼ 3.9, p ¼ 0.002] and no significant differences in the other two spectral regions.

Thresholds were higher in the asynchronous than in the synchronous condition for conditions when the target and interferer were in the same frequency region, consistent with earlier findings of Carlyon (1996a,b).
Overall, the results from experiment 1 indicate that pitch interference remains high, despite target bandwidths that include up to 10 components.

Even though the results are marginally better than those of Kreft et al. (2013), average F0DLs are still around 20%-30% in the best case scenarios (i.e., non-overlapping off-frequency interferers), which is considerably poorer than the 6% F0DLs needed to discriminate a semitone in music.
These results suggest that accurately perceiving multiple pitches via temporal envelope cues has severe limitations, even with relatively wideband stimuli.
One question that arises is how much improvement can be achieved by further increasing the bandwidth of these stimuli.
Experiment 2 aims to address this by measuring the effect of systematically increasing bandwidth on F0DLs without interferers.

div.head: Experiment 2: Effect of bandwidth on F0DLs

p.s: The results from experiment 1 show that F0 discrimination remains very poor in the presence of an interferer when the bandwidth of the target is 1250 Hz, even when the interferers are spectrally remote.

It is unclear whether the lack of a strong bandwidth effect is something specific to pitch discrimination interference, or whether it is observed in F0 discrimination, even in the absence of an interferer.

Houtsma and Smurzynski (1990) found that pitch discrimination improved with increasing number of components, although they found that performance reached an asymptote with around ten components, similar to the number used in our experiment 1.

However, one study has reported F0DLs as low as 1.5%-2% for stimuli with only unresolved harmonics, when the bandwidth was very wide (highpass filtered at 2000 and 4500 Hz for F0s ranging from 100 to 250 Hz (Kaernbach and Bering, 2001).

The aim of this experiment was to measure F0DLs directly as a function of stimulus bandwidth in the absence of an interferer to determine whether performance could be improved by presenting listeners with even wider bandwidths than were used in experiment 1.
The target stimulus was a complex harmonic tone, presented in sine phase, with a fundamental frequency (F0) of 115 Hz, bandpass filtered to contain only spectrally unresolved harmonics.
The lower corner frequency of the passband was either 2000 or 5000 Hz.
The five bandwidths used were 1250, 2500, 5000, 10 000, and 15 000 Hz.
The stimulus was filtered with slopes of 72 dB/octave outside the passband.
The duration of the target was 300 ms (including 10-ms raised-cosine onset and offset ramps).
The level was set at a nominal 50 dB SPL per component, but was roved on each presentation within a range of 66 dB to reduce potential loudness cues.

The stimuli were embedded in a background of TEN, bandpass filtered between 20 Hz and the lower corner frequency of the target stimulus, presented at 40 dB SPL (10 dB below the level per component in the stimuli) within the ERB centered at 1 kHz.
Eight new participants ranging in age from 18 to 24 years with audiometric thresholds no greater than 15 dB HL at octave frequencies from 250 to 8000 Hz were recruited for this experiment.
The recruitment criteria and procedures were the same as in experiment 1.
Three adaptive runs per condition were administered and the order of conditions was randomized between participants and repetitions.
All analyses were carried out on the log-transformed F0DLs.

The mean data are shown in Fig. 2. A repeated-measures ANOVA was carried out with the F0DLs as the dependent variable, and within-subject factors of lower corner frequency (2000 or 5000 Hz) and stimulus bandwidth (1250, 2500, 5000, 10 000, or 15 000 Hz).

A significant overall effect of the lowest frequency was observed [F(1,7) ¼ 15.2, p ¼ 0.005], but there was no significant effect of bandwidth [F(4,28) ¼ 0.77, p ¼ 0.6] and no significant interaction [F(4,28) ¼ 0.96, p ¼ 0.45].
The pattern of results is consistent with that of Houtsma and Smurzynski (1990), suggesting no improvements in F0DL with increasing bandwidth once the number of components exceeds about 10.
The absolute values of our F0DLs, at least in the condition where the stimuli was high-pass filtered at 2000 Hz, were about 4%-5% on average.

These values are similar to those observed in a study by Bernstein and Oxenham (2003), but are higher (poorer) than those reported by other studies (Deeks et al., 2013;Gockel et al., 1999;Houtsma and Smurzynski, 1990;Kaernbach and Bering, 2001;Wang et al., 2012).
The discrepancies between our thresholds and the other studies could be due to a lack of training.
The participants in the current study did not go through training before the task, which could be a reason for the higher thresholds.
However, no significant improvement was observed across the three runs of each condition based on a repeated measures ANOVA showing no overall main effect of run number [F(2,22) ¼ 1.97, p ¼ 0.089].
Additionally, recruitment to our study did not require any degree of musical training, and the eight participants in this experiment had an average of only 3.8 years of musical training.

Several studies have shown that musicians tend to have lower F0DLs than nonmusicians (Madsen et al., 2017;Ruggles et al., 2014), although the differences tend to disappear after non-musicians have received 6-8 h of training (Micheyl et al., 2006).
Overall, we find that F0DLs do not improve significantly with increasing bandwidth, even for bandwidths up to 15 000 Hz.
These findings indicate that the bandwidth of 1250 Hz used in experiment 1 was probably not a limiting factor.
The aim of this study was to test whether temporal-envelope coding of F0 is less susceptible to interference if the stimulus is presented over a wider bandwidth than had been tested in the past.
In CI users, this would correspond to presenting the signal over multiple electrodes.

The results from experiment 1 showed that interference remained very strong, and F0DLs remained very poor, even when the target and interferer stimulus bandwidth was greater than 1000 Hz, so that the target stimulus included around 10 harmonics.
This was true for interferers that were presented synchronously as well as asynchronously.
Thresholds for stimuli with asynchronous interferers were poorer than with synchronous interferers when the target and interferer were presented to the same spectral region.

This finding is consistent with the data from Carlyon (1996a,b) who also showed a detrimental effect of asynchrony between the target and interferer on listeners ability to discriminate the F0 of targets containing only unresolved harmonics.

A later study by Gockel et al. (2004) found that asynchrony can help performance when the target and interferer are in different, non-overlapping spectral regions, whereas our data did not show that same trend.
The poor performance in the presence of interferers was accompanied by poor F0DLs even without interferers: F0DLs without interferers were generally higher than 6% (one semitone).
This outcome suggested that performance might have been improved by extending the bandwidth of the target even further than the 1250 Hz used in experiment 1.
However, the results from experiment 2 suggest that this is not the case: increasing the target bandwidth from 1250 to 15 000 Hz resulted in no significant improvement in F0DLs.
Overall, F0DLs based only on the temporal-envelope cues provided by spectrally unresolved harmonics remain high even with wide stimulus bandwidths.

Most importantly, pitch interference remains very high under these conditions, suggesting that it is generally not possible to perceive the pitch of one stimulus in the presence of another harmonic stimulus when both consist of unresolved harmonics, even when they are spectrally separated.
This in turn suggests that it may not be possible to perceive multiple simultaneous pitches, which will limit the ability to perceive harmony.
The implication of this conclusion is that CI users, who rely on temporal-envelope cues for the perception of F0 of complex tones, are unlikely to be able to perceive multiple simultaneous pitches.
Fig. 1. (Color online) Mean and individual results from the conditions without, and with synchronous or asynchronous interferers.
The different groups of bars indicate the different types of interferer F0.
The different bars indicate the spectral region of the interferer.
The dots represent individual subjects.
Fig. 2. Mean results for thresholds without interferers across increasing bandwidths for two different high-pass cutoff frequencies, 2000 and 5000 Hz.
